subject: Critical Thinking
title: Anchoring Bias: The First Number Wins
description: A 60-second lesson on Anchoring Bias: The First Number Wins.

hook.text: A store marks a jacket at $500, then 'discounts' it to $250. You feel a bargain. The jacket cost $80 to make.

buildup.text: Anchoring: the first number you see biases every subsequent estimate â€” even when it's completely irrelevant.

discovery.text: Tversky & Kahneman spun a random wheel, then asked people to estimate African UN countries.

twist.text: Even experts anchor. Real estate agents shown different listing prices valued the same house differently.

climax.text: Anchoring works because System 1 seizes the first number and System 2 adjusts â€” but always insufficiently.

punchline.text: Whoever sets the first number controls the negotiation.

quiz.question: Why does anchoring bias occur?
options: The first number frames all subsequent judgments, and adjustment is insufficient
